newsitem.title: USA: Armstrong seeks to stop Sommer-Tarkett deal.
newsitem.headline: Armstrong seeks to stop Sommer-Tarkett deal.

text.p: Armstrong World Industries Inc said Monday it was seeking an injunction to block the merger of Sommer Allibert SA of France and Tarkett AG of Germany.

Armstrong, which makes floor coverings and ceilings systems, said in a statement it was seeking to stop the deal based on alleged breach of a confidentiality agreement and other understandings between it and Sommer.
Armstrong, in a petition filed in federal court in Philadelphia, alleged that Sommer used Armstrong's confidential information to attract Tarkett.
It also said it had amended a complaint filed in the same court on June 9, adding Tarkett and Marc Assa, a Sommer official, as defendants. Sommer had denied the allegations.
In the amended complaint, Armstrong said it alleged that Tarkett aided and abetted Sommer's alleged fraud on Armstrong.
Sommer and Tarkett announced a proposed merger on May 28. The deal would create one of the world's largest companies in the floor covering business.
On June 9 Armstrong launched a C$23-a-share bid for Domco Inc, a Canadian flooring maker in which Sommer is majority shareholder.
On the day it made the bid, Armstrong revealed it had been in talks with Sommer for over 12 months on the possibility of combining their floor covering operations.
Armstrong said that in response to Sommer's solicitation, it offered on April 17 to buy Sommer's flooring assets, including Domco, for $775 million.
Sommer rejected the offer on May 26 and accepted Tarkett's $565 million merger bid soon after.

On July 2 Armstrong reduced the minimum number of shares to be tendered in its Domco offer, to 51 percent from 66-2/3 percent, and proposed to buy new shares from Domco to meet the lower threshold. It also extended the offer to August 15.
